BILL NUMBER:S1623

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the general business law, in relation to
accessibility by blind and visually impaired persons
to automated teller machines

PURPOSE:
This legislation would better enable blind and visually handicapped
persons to utilize automated teller machines.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
A new section 399-i is added to the general business law. Section
399-i(1) defines the term "automated teller machine".

Section 399-e(2) Provides that no ATMs may be sold In the State of
New York without raised lettering and/or Braille lettering or unless
the number size or font can be enlarged by the push of a button.

Section 399-e(3) Provides that every ATM provider shall provide verbal
assistance or instruction in Braille in the use of ATMs provided by
such provider.

Section 399-e(4) Provides that in the event that an ATM is not
modified in accordance with section 2 the machine provider shall make
modifications or adaptations to make the machine fully accessible and
usable by blind and visually impaired persons.

Section 399-e(5) Provides for a civil fine of2,500 dollars for each
machine sold in violation of section 2 and a civil fine of 1,000
dollars per day per machine for violations of section 3 or 4.

EXISTING LAW:
There are many laws to protect the civil rights of blind and visually
impaired persons, however, there is currently no requirement for
automated teller machines to be equipped to provide greater access
for visually impaired persons.

JUSTIFICATION:
In today's modern, fast-paced economy many people enjoy the convenience
of using automated teller machines rather than waiting in line to do
their banking. Unfortunately, although some ATMs are accessible to
blind and visually impaired people most are not. Additionally, even
in the event that an ATM is equipped with raised or Braille letters
and numbers on the keypad the on-screen visual display is often too
small to be properly read. Technology exists where on-screen
information can be audibly verbalized to facilitate use by blind and
visually impaired persons. New York State has a long history and
tradition of helping those with disabilities overcome their physical

limitations and become more active in society. This bill continues
this great tradition.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
S.5808 of 2007
05/11/07 Referred to Consumer Protection
S.135 of 2009
01/07/09 Referred to Consumer Protection
01/06/10 Referred to Consumer Protection

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

LOCAL FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the 1st of January next succeeding the
date on which it shall have become a law, provided, however, that
effective immediately, the addition, amendment, and/or repeal of any
rules or regulations necessary for the implementation of the
foregoing section of this act on its effective date is authorized and
directed to be made and completed on or before such effective date.
